pullRequest.body:
This adds two lemmas that allow to translate function congruence into liftFun, as required by `Quotient.map` and similar functions.


---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [a26a4c66c0](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/15127/commits/a26a4c66c000f7108a9ab76738dc9116d0d41580)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

#### Declarations diff

`--++ map`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
I have the same impression.

Maybe this is correct, maybe proofs would be shorter, but not necessarily more readable. The point of this is that congruence is very often not phrased in terms of `⇒` and thus this makes things more readable, in my opinion.

Unfortunately also the classical definition of congruence (used here) does not seem to be reduce to `⇒` so that just passing the proofs of congruence to `map` would not work without these lemmas.

> Unfortunately also the classical definition of congruence (used here) does not seem to be reduce to `⇒` 

I would claim that classically, the order of universal quantifiers doesn't really exist, and that is just a concern than appears in formalization.

> so that just passing the proofs of congruence to `map` would not work without these lemmas.

All you have to do is replace `intro x₁ x₂ y₁ y₂ hx hy` in your proof with `intro x₁ x₂ hx y₁ y₂ hy`

> All you have to do is replace intro x₁ x₂ y₁ y₂ hx hy in your proof with intro x₁ x₂ hx y₁ y₂ hy

In my opinion the point here is not about proofs, it's about defining quotients with `Quotient.map`. You can't pass a proof of congruence to it because it takes in a `(h : ((· ≈ ·) ⇒ (· ≈ ·)) f f)` instead of something of type `: (h : ∀ a b, a ≈ b → f a = f b)` or its generalization `(h : ∀ x y, R x y → S (f x) (f y))`, which is why I used this lemmas.

Maybe the reasonable thing instead would be defining a  `map'` that takes in an `(h : ∀ x y, R x y → S (f x) (f y))`, and similarly for `map₂`?
Could you give an example of the type of code that you're claiming doesn't currently work? I suspect the fix for the example you give is as simple as adding an `@` somewhere.

Here's what I think is a direct refutation of your claim:
```lean
import Mathlib

variable
  {α β}
  [sα : Setoid α] [sβ : Setoid β]
  (f : α → β)
  (hf : ∀ a b, a ≈ b → f a ≈ f b) -- this does not use `⇒`, but it works fine anyway

def foo : Quotient sα → Quotient sβ := Quotient.map f hf
```
`(h : ∀ a b, a ≈ b → f a = f b)` is the argument type taken by `Quotient.lift`, not `Quotient.map`.

Sorry, it took me a bit to get around back to writing this example properly. This works:
```lean
import Mathlib
variable (n : ℕ)
instance instEq : Equivalence (Nat.ModEq n) := ⟨refl, Nat.ModEq.symm, Nat.ModEq.trans⟩
instance instS : Setoid ℕ := ⟨(Nat.ModEq n), instEq n⟩
theorem add_congr : ∀ (a b c d : ℕ), (h₁ : a ≡ b [MOD n]) → (h₂ : c ≡ d [MOD n]) → (a+c) ≡ b+d [MOD n] :=
  fun _ _ _ _ h₁ h₂ => h₁.add h₂

def setoid_add {n}: Quotient (instS n) → Quotient (instS n) → Quotient (instS n) :=
  Quotient.map₂  Nat.add (congr_liftFun₂ (add_congr n))
    (sa := instS n) (sb := instS n) (sc := instS n)
```

but if I change it to 

```lean
def setoid_add {n}: Quotient (instS n) → Quotient (instS n) → Quotient (instS n) :=
  Quotient.map₂  Nat.add (add_congr n)
    (sa := instS n) (sb := instS n) (sc := instS n)
 ```
    
I get the error:
```lean
application type mismatch
  Quotient.map₂ Nat.add ⋯
argument
  add_congr n
has type
  ∀ (a b c d : ℕ), a ≡ b [MOD n] → c ≡ d [MOD n] → a + c ≡ b + d [MOD n] : Prop
but is expected to have type
  ((fun x x_1 ↦ x ≈ x_1) ⇒ (fun x x_1 ↦ x ≈ x_1) ⇒ fun x x_1 ↦ x ≈ x_1) Nat.add Nat.add : Prop
```

I think the problem is on the `map₂` case Lean doesn't manage to see through the definition. An example more or less along these lines was my original motivation. I should have described this with the PR originally, sorry for that (and thanks for the reviews, I appreciate you taking the time to discuss this with me!)

> `(h : ∀ a b, a ≈ b → f a = f b)` is the argument type taken by `Quotient.lift`, not `Quotient.map`.

right, but I don't see why map wouldn't take the same to be honest, that's the point. Of course we can use lift, but then what's the point of map. I think map is convenient, but it's not convenient if it doesn't accept a congruence proof but rather only this `⇒` generalization that doesn't unify with a congruence proof.

In this case the spelling I'd advocate is:
```lean
import Mathlib
variable (n : ℕ)
instance instEq : Equivalence (Nat.ModEq n) := ⟨refl, Nat.ModEq.symm, Nat.ModEq.trans⟩
instance instS' : Setoid ℕ := ⟨(Nat.ModEq n), instEq n⟩
theorem add_congr : ∀ {a b c d : ℕ}, (h₁ : a ≡ b [MOD n]) → (h₂ : c ≡ d [MOD n]) → (a+c) ≡ b+d [MOD n] :=
  fun h₁ h₂ => h₁.add h₂

def setoid_add {n}: Quotient (instS' n) → Quotient (instS' n) → Quotient (instS' n) :=
  Quotient.map₂  Nat.add fun _ _ h₁ _ _ h₂ => add_congr _ h₁ h₂
```
where `fun` does the work of adjusting the argument order

Yeah, that works, but then you need to see under the definitions/implementation details to reorder those arguments. I think it's good design to have abstractions that are familiar to people. In my opinion, `map₂` (or at least some `map₂'`) should take these congruence proofs, not an inline anonymous function rearranging the arguments to make it fit some other generalization. I'm happy to adapt the PR to provide that `map₂ '`, but if you think this abstraction is not useful or helpful, feel free to close this PR.

This PR looks a bit stuck. I agree with Eric and Yury above that those lemmas look redundant.

In fact, it seems that this PR is trying to fix the symptom, not the problem. And I diagnose the problem as being `Quotient.map` taking this weird `((· ≈ ·) ⇒ (· ≈ ·)) f f` argument (which is not even shorter to write than `∀ a b, a ≈ b → f a ≈ f b`! but that was different in Lean 3).

Would you like to recycle this PR to change the proof argument to `Quotient.map`, rather than adding those two lemmas?

Thanks for that @YaelDillies, I very much agree with that take. I wasn't aware this was a remnant from Lean 3 and thought it was for some generalization, so I didn't think that refactor was up for discussion. 

I've repurposed this PR, removing the two not-so-useful lemmas and instead changing the congruence hypothesis. Sorry it took so long, sometimes I miss the notifications on github.
My suspicion is that any proof that uses these lemmas would be shorter without using them.
My suspicion is that any proof that uses these lemmas would be shorter without using them.

Thanks for taking this back up! Looks like the build is failing.

On the topic of github notifications, what I found works for me is to look at all notifications in my inbox, read and unread, and mark each of them done once I have treated it.

```suggestion
    (h : ∀ x y, x ≈ y → f x ≈ f y) : ((· ≈ ·) ⇒ (· ≈ ·)) f f := h
```
which is to say, the proof is just "you already gave me the proof"!

```suggestion
protected def map (f : α → β) (h : ∀ ⦃a b : α⦄, a ≈ b → f a ≈ f b) : Quotient sa → Quotient sb :=
```
will probably be much nicer to use

and here too
```suggestion
protected def map₂ (f : α → β → γ) (h : ∀ ⦃a₁ a₂ b₁ b₂⦄, a₁ ≈ a₂ → b₁ ≈ b₂ → f a₁ b₁ ≈ f a₂ b₂) :
```

Very empirical, but grouping semi-implicit arguments like this is usually better
```suggestion
protected def map₂ (f : α → β → γ) (h : ∀ ⦃a₁ a₂⦄, a₁ ≈ a₂ → ∀ ⦃b₁ b₂⦄, b₁ ≈ b₂ → f a₁ b₁ ≈ f a₂ b₂) :
```
interesting, I'm happy to change that, but curious why that grouping is usually better? (It feels strange to split up the all quantifier)
This way, the `⦃b₁ b₂⦄` binders don't turn implicit when you only provide the `a₁ ≈ a₂` argument

```suggestion
   (h : ∀ ⦃a₁ a₂⦄, a₁ ≈ a₂ → ∀ ⦃b₁ b₂⦄, b₁ ≈ b₂ → f a₁ b₁ ≈ f a₂ b₂) :
```

Do you know you can do
```suggestion
theorem map₂_mk (f : α → β → γ) (h) (x : α) (y : β) :
```
?
I didn't know, no, thanks!

```suggestion
theorem map_mk (f : α → β) (h) (x : α) :
```

`fun` has very low precedence precisely for this kind of situations
```suggestion
  Quot.lift (fun x => Quot.mk rb (f x)) fun x y hra ↦ Quot.sound <|  h x y hra
```

pullRequest.title: feat(Quot): add simple lemmas on function congruence
